metadata.title: Surface energy effect on buckling behavior of the functionally graded nano-shell covered with piezoelectric nano-layers under torque

sections.text:
International Journal of Mechanical Sciences 133 (2017) 662–673
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
International Journal of Mechanical Sciences
journal homepage: www.elsevier.com/locate/ijmecsci
Surface energy effect on buckling behavior of the functionally graded
nano-shell covered with piezoelectric nano-layers under torque
Chang-Song Zhu, Xue-Qian Fang ∗ , Jin-Xi Liu
Department of Engineering Mechanics, Shijiazhuang Tiedao University, Shijiazhuang, 050043, China
a r t i c l e i n f o
Keywords: Functionally graded nano-shell Piezoelectric nano-layer Surface/interface energy Torsional buckling
a b s t r a c t
In this paper, based on the electro-elastic surface/interface theory, the size-dependent effect on the torsional buckling behavior of functionally graded (FG) cylindrical nano-shell covered with piezoelectric nano-layers is studied. According to the classical shell theory together with von-Karman-Donnell type kinematics of nonlinearity, the primary formulations are given. The total energy of the nano-shell is derived by introducing the constitute relations for piezoelectric surfaces and interfaces. The principle of minimum potential energy is employed to establish the governing differential equations. An analytical solution is firstly presented, and then the generalized differential quadrature (GDQ) method is used to obtain the numerical results of nano-shells with different boundary conditions. Afterwards, the results without surface/interface effect are compared with the datum in the open literatures, and some numerical examples are presented to investigate the effect of surface/interface parameters and power-law index on the critical buckling load of the nano-shell.

. Introduction
With the development of material science, piezoelectric materials re well-known for capturing the surrounding energy to produce the iezoelectricity, which makes them have a great number of applications n the smart devices [1–4] . In recent years, as many structures tend o miniaturization, piezoelectric nano-structures, such as nano-beams,
ano-plates and nano-shells, have attracted wide attention in the microano-electromechanical systems (MEMS/NEMS) [5–8] . Different from he piezoelectric bulks, piezoelectric nano-structures have unique elecrical, mechanical and physical properties, which leads to many potenial applications [5,6] .
Due to the fact that the nano-structure is a system at the nanometer cale, the nano-sized effect cannot be ignored when predicting its behavors, which has been demonstrated by experimental results [9,11] and tomistic simulations [10,12] . Since the classical theory is scale-free, t fails to predict the size-dependent response of nano-structures. Conequently, to consider the small scale effect, some non-classical theoies are proposed, such as strain gradient theory [13–15] , couple stress heory [16–18] , nonlocal theory [19–21] and surface elasticity theory 22–24] . Among the non-classical theories, the surface elasticity theory aised by Gurtin and Murdoch has been widely used to study the vi-
ration, bending, buckling and postbuckling behaviors of elastic nanotructures in recent years [25–38] . This can be attributed to the fact hat in nano-structures, the ratio of atomic–size surface/interface to the

olume is very high, and the behaviors of nano-structures are signifcantly related with the high surface/interface ratio. To describe the
ano-sized effect, the surface/interface effect should be considered. Sat-
sfactorily, the surface elasticity theory can make it by considering the urface/interface energy. However, it is worth noting that the surface lasticity theory cannot predict the effect of surface/interface piezoelecricity. To consider the size-dependent response of piezoelectric nanotructures, the electro-elastic surface/interface theory was introduced
y Huang and Yu [39] , and this theory is employed to carry out the resent work.
In recent years, on the basis of non-classical theories, many theoretcal investigations have been carried out for the elastic nano-structures. or example, based on the nonlocal theory and four different beam theoies, the bending, buckling and vibration behaviors of nano-beams were tudied by Reddy, and the effect of nonlocal parameter on the maxi-
um deflection, critical buckling load and natural frequency were disussed [40] . According to the surface elasticity theory, the effect of surace stress on free vibration behavior of nano-plates was investigated y Ansari and Sahmani, and some numerical examples were presented o quantitatively evaluate the influences of surface parameters on the atural frequencies of nano-plates [26] . Besides, within the framework f surface elasticity theory, the nonlinear free vibration and nonlinear ostbuckling behaviors of nano-plates were studied by Wang and Wang 29,37] . The nonlinear buckling and postbuckling behaviors of shear eformable nano-shell under radial compressive load were studied by

With the rapid development of piezoelectric materials, a number of orks have also been carried out in the presence of different piezoelecric nano-structures. For instance, based on the consistent couple stress heory and Timoshenko beam theory, the electro-mechanical bending nd vibration behaviors of a piezoelectric nano-beam were studied by
eni, and the effect of different parameters on the maximum deflec-
ion and natural frequency was presented [41] . Within the framework f electro-elastic surface/interface theory, the scattering of compressive
aves around a piezoelectric nano-particle in a polymer matrix was tudied, and the surface/interface effect on the electric displacement nd dynamic stress around the nano-sized particle was presented [42] .
ccording to the modified couple stress theory combined with Eulerernoulli beam theory, the electro-mechanical buckling analysis of a G nano-bridge was studied by Shojaeian and Beni, and the influence of ower law index, scale parameter and distance between two settled and
ovable electrodes was presented [43] . In addition, the size-dependent
uckling, free vibration and bending behaviors of FG piezoelectric nanoeams were investigated by using the consistent couple stress theory and uler-Bernoulli beam theory [44] . Zhang et al. studied the surface effect n the anti-plane shear wave propagation in an infinite piezoelectric ano-plate based on electro-elastic surface/interface model [45] . A sizeependent model for the vibration and buckling analysis of piezoelecric nano-plates was developed by using electro-elastic surface/interface heory [46] .
Due to the fact that the nano-shell is a basic element in numerous ano-structures, a detailed and further study on nano-shells should be arried out to obtain the desired material properties and design the perect nano-shell. In recent years, there have been some publications on he vibration [47–55] and buckling [56–63] behaviors of nano-shells. or example, a size-dependent model for vibration analysis of a sand-
ich nano-shell with FG materials was studied based on the couple stress heory [53] . The thermo-electro-mechanical vibration of a piezoelectric ano-shell with different boundary conditions was investigated by usng the nonlocal theory and Love’s thin shell theory [54] . According o nonlocal shell model, Ansari et al. studied axial buckling analysis f a multi-walled carbon nanotube under thermal load [57] . Based on urface/interface elasticity theory, the postbuckling behavior of an im-
erfect and pressured FG nano-shell in the thermal field was studied y Sahmani and Aghdam, and the effects of power-law index, thermal nvironments and geometric imperfection on the end-shortening and
aximum deflection were discussed [59] . The size-dependent buckling odels for a FG piezoelectric nano-shell under lateral pressure and an
nisotropic piezoelectric nano-shell under combined axial and lateral oads were presented by using the new modified couple stress theory, nd the influences of material length scale parameter, thickness and ap-
lied voltage on critical buckling load were analyzed [61,62] . Within the ramework of surface elasticity theory, the nonlinear buckling and postuckling analysis of a piezoelectric nano-shell under combined compresive load and electrical load was studied, and the effect of surface paameters and electrical load on the postbuckling load-deflection curves nd load-shortening curves was discussed [63] .
It is worth noting that the buckling of nano-shells is an essential mater. Due to the fact that it is very difficulty to obtain the stability soluions for a nano-shell subjected to torsional load, the torsional buckling nalysis of nano-shells is more attractive, which can be found in some tudies [64–74] . For instance, the buckling analysis of a single walled arbon nanotube subjected to torque was conducted by using the nonloal elasticity theory and molecular dynamic simulation [65] . According o a continuum elastic double-shell model, the buckling and postbucking analysis on a double-walled carbon nanotube under torque was inestigated by Yao and Han, and the postbuckling relationship between he torque and the angle of twist was given [70] . On the basis of nonlocal lasticity and piezoelectricity theory, the torsional buckling analysis of n embedded armchair double-walled nanotube under electric load and
hermal load was studied, and the influence of nonlocal parameter, temerature change, piezoelectric and dielectric constants on critical bucking load was presented [72] . A size-dependent model for the buckling nalysis of a FG nano-shell under torque was developed by using the
odified couple stress theory [74] . Through detailed calculations, the
ffect of length scale parameter, power-law index and aspect ratio on ritical buckling load was discussed. Though some investigations have een performed on the torsional buckling analysis of nano-shells, up to resent time, the electro-elastic surface/interface energy effect on the orsional buckling of a FG nano-shell with piezoelectric layers has not een carried out.
In the present study, the buckling behavior of a FG cylindrical nanohell embedded with piezoelectric layers subjected to torque is investiated. The electro-elastic coupling surface/interface model is employed o derive the total energy of the nano-shell, and the principle of mini-
um potential energy is used to obtain the governing differential equaions. Finally, some numerical results are illustrated to show the effects f surface/interface properties, geometric parameters and power-law inex on the critical buckling load of the nano-shell.
. Mathematical formulation
A FG cylindrical nano-shell embedded with piezoelectric nano-layers s considered. The length is L nm. The thickness of FG layer is 2 h nm, and hat of piezoelectric layers is t nm. The radius of mid-surface is denoted s R , as shown in Fig. 1 . A twisting moment T is exerted on the two nds of nano-shell. With the origin of coordinate system located on the
iddle surface of nano-shell, the coordinates of a typical point in the
xial, circumferential and radius directions are described by x , 𝜃, and z , espectively. E F and 𝜐𝐹 represent Young modulus and Poisson ratio of G cylindrical nano-shell. odel, the surface/interface layers are different from the bulk, and posess their own electro-mechanical properties. iezoelectric layer and the FG nano-shell is depicted by I 2. . Numerical results and analysis
In this section, the surface/interface energy effect on the torsional uckling of the nano-shell subjected to torsion is analyzed. The FG cylinrical nano-shell in the following examples is supposed to be made p of Zirconia located at the lower layer and Aluminum at the uper layer, and the material properties are as follows: E B = 151 GPa, 𝐵 = 0.3, E T = 70 GPa, 𝜐𝑇 = 0.3 [78] . Piezoelectric layers are assumed o be composed of BaTiO 3 and the material properties are presented s: C 11 P = 166 GPa, C 12 P = 77 GPa, e 31 P = − 4.4C/m 2 , e 32 P = − 4.4C/m 2 , 33 P = 12.6 ×10 − 9 F/m [83] . The voltage applied to the nano-shell is elected as G = 0.01 V. In addition, it should be noted that detailed surace/interface material parameters can be obtained from experimental nvestigation and atomistic simulation. The critical torsional moment is important for the stability of piezolectric nano-shells. To find the effects of surface/interface energy on he critical torsional moment, the following numerical examples with ifferent surface/interface material parameters are given. To this end, he dimensionless critical torsional moment is defined as T cr / T cr 0 , where cr and T cr 0 represent the non-classical (with surface/interface effects) nd classical (without surface/interface effects) critical torsional mo-
ent, respectively.
The effects of surface residual stress and interface residual stress on he dimensionless critical torsional moment are, respectively, shown in ig. 2 a and b. In Fig. 2 a, it can be seen that the dimensionless critial torsional moment shows significant variation with the surface and nterface properties when the dimension of layers is selected as nanocale. This phenomenon results from the large surface/interface ratio o the volume, which is an important character of nano-shells. A negaive surface/interface residual stress will bring a small critical torsional
oment. A positive surface/interface residual stress will bring a large ritical torsional moment. In addition, the effects of 𝜎𝑆 0 on the dimenionless critical torsional moment are great when the thickness of nanohell is small enough, and the effects vanish little by little when the ano-thickness becomes large. This can be attributed to the truth that he energy possessed by surface section is significant for volume secion when the thickness of nano-shell is very thin. However, when it ecomes thick, the energy of volume section is much greater than that f surface section, and so the surface energy can be ignored. The almost ame results can be obtained from Fig. 2 b, and it can be concluded that
he effects of surface and interface residual stress on the dimensionless ritical torsional moment are the same.
Fig. 3 a and b illustrate the effects of different 𝜆S and 𝜆I on the dimenionless critical torsional moment of FG nano-shell, respectively. From ig. 3 a, it can be seen that T cr / T cr 0 increases with increasing surface amé’s constant 𝜆S when 𝜆S is a positive value. The converse result can e observed when 𝜆S is a negative value. In Fig. 3 b, the same concluions can be drawn. By comparing the results in Fig. 3 a and b, it is clear hat the effect of 𝜆S on dimensionless critical torsional moment is greater han that of the same value of 𝜆I when the thickness is very thin. For exmple, when the thickness is 5 nm, the dimensionless critical torsional
oment is 1.103 for 𝜆S = 20 N/m and 1.074 for 𝜆I = 20 N/m. Fig. 4 a and b illustrate the effects of different 𝜇S and 𝜇I on the dimenionless critical torsional moment with the thickness of FG nano-shell, espectively. By Comparing the results in Fig. 3 a and b, the same conlusions can be observed, which may be attributed to the fact that 𝜆S , I , 𝜇S and 𝜇I are all surface/interface Lamé’s constants.

. Conclusion
Based on electro-elasticity surface/interface theory, the sizeependent effects on the torsional buckling behavior of FG cylindrical ano-shell covered with piezoelectric nano-layers are investigated. Funamental formulations are given on the basis of the classical shell theory s well as the von-Karman-Donnell type kinematics of nonlinearity. The overning equations are obtained by using the principle of minimum otential energy. It can be found that the effect of surface Lamé’s contants on the dimensionless critical torsional moment is greater than that f interface Lamé’s constants, and the influence of surface residual stress n the dimensionless critical torsional moment is identical with interace residual stress. For surface piezoelectric constants, the dimensioness critical torsional moment varies more sharply than others when the hickness is very thin. Besides, the critical torsional moment increases
ith the increase of applied voltage when the applied voltage is posiive, and the converse results are obtained when the applied voltage is egative.
This work can provide significant reference in predicting the trend f surface/interface effect on the mechanical behavior of the nano-shell, nd it is also expected to be useful for designing and improving the nanohells based devices in NEMS.

metadata.abstractText: In this paper, based on the electro-elastic surface/interface theory, the size-dependent effect on the torsional buckling behavior of functionally graded (FG) cylindrical nano-shell covered with piezoelectric nano-layers is studied. According to the classical shell theory together with von-Karman-Donnell type kinematics of nonlinearity, the primary formulations are given. The total energy of the nano-shell is derived by introducing the constitute relations for piezoelectric surfaces and interfaces. The principle of minimum potential energy is employed to establish the governing differential equations. An analytical solution is firstly presented, and then the generalized differential quadrature (GDQ) method is used to obtain the numerical results of nano-shells with different boundary conditions. Afterwards, the results without surface/interface effect are compared with the datum in the open literatures, and some numerical examples are presented to investigate the effect of surface/interface parameters and power-law index on the critical buckling load of the nano-shell. © 2017 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
